body:
There will be no more things shipped for v2.

If `dotnet test` is killing mid-execution, then there's nothing we can do about that. Our console runner supports two-stage cancellation: one where we request cancellation, and if you hit Ctrl+C a second time it just kills everything and exits.
Thank you, I see. How would one handle cancellation in the test if there's no `CancellationToken` support on test methods though?
There is no way today to handle it in the tests. The wait that's being done in that case ensures no new tests will be started.

issue.title: Handle cancellations gracefully (OSOE-362)

repository.name: UI-Testing-Toolbox
repository.description: Web UI testing toolbox for Orchard Core applications with Selenium. It discovers so many issues that you'll get impostor syndrome.

issue.body:
[This xUnit bug](https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/2008 "https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/2008") was fixed for this but will only be part of xUnit v3. Once that's released, `TestContext` [will contain a `CancellationToken`](https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/345#issuecomment-1451388078) which is accessible as `TestContext.Current.CancellationToken`. The latter should be passed down so canceled tests won't e.g. leave browser windows or ChromeDriver processes open.

[Hooking into the console cancel event](https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/2008#issuecomment-588321441 "https://github.com/xunit/xunit/issues/2008#issuecomment-588321441") won't work with `dotnet test`. 

[Jira issue](https://lombiq.atlassian.net/browse/OSOE-362)

body:
> There is no way today to handle it in the tests. The wait that's being done in that case ensures no new tests will be started.

I think we can say something a bit stronger, actually: You don't _want_ to handle this in tests, as it means the behavior of your test is dependent on a user action and could cause a silent passing test. Probably should go into an Architecture Decision Log on test behavior.

@jzabroski As it turns out, between the time I wrote that comment and now, we've added support for cancellation tokens in unit tests, available via `TestContext.Current.CancellationToken`, and a test can request self-cancellation via `TestContext.Current.CancelCurrentTest`.

This is mostly so that tests can stop running when they've been cancelled, and not about any attempt to clean up (though some may choose to try to use it this way, even if that's not what was intended).
